awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: A Rapid Multi-Contaminant Degradation System for Water Wells
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to improve the quality of well water for drinking. As of 2019, 43 million Americans do not have access to public water and rely on private sources. Unlike public water systems, private wells are not regulated, placing these Americans at an increased health risk from waterborne contaminants. This lack of access results in socioeconomic health disparities. Treating odorous water and other organic and biological contaminants requires multiple treatment systems that add significant complexity and costs. This project will develop a new water treatment system that simultaneously treats odorous water, recalcitrant organics (e.g., pharmaceuticals), and biological pathogens without the addition of chemicals.

The proposed project will advance the understanding of inhibiting agents in photocatalytic water treatment systems. Understanding these fouling mechanisms is critical to developing a robust photocatalyst for water treatment. This project will identify the primary photocatalyst inhibitors in groundwater sources and determine the mechanism for their inhibition, e.g., bulk quenching or surface fouling. Analytical techniques to study the binding between fouling agents and photocatalyst surfaces include several surface-sensitive spectroscopy methods, such as nano-Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (nano-FTIR) and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (TERS).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University and A&M College

por.por_cntn:
Water treatment by heterogeneous photocatalysts has been an active area of research for decades. Unfortunately, due to carrier recombination, mass transfer limitations, and poor light management, the technology has struggled to go beyond laboratory studies. Hydrogen sulfide is a common groundwater contaminant in private water wells, which requires specialized treatment methods. Additional biological contaminants and micropollutants often coexist with H2S in private water sources, requiring complex treatment trains in these multicomponent streams.

This project investigates the efficacy and stability of a heterogenous photocatalytic system for removing H2S and other co-contaminants from groundwater. We employed a mesoporous TiO2 (P25) photocatalyst immobilized on a macroporous fused silica fiber sheet. This dual-porosity photocatalyst was loaded into a flow cell and illuminated with UVA (365 nm) LEDs. Our immobilized reactor avoids the additional separation step required by typical slurry reactors.

Generally, immobilizing the catalyst on a UV-transparent support improves light management by overcoming shadowing effects found in slurry reactors, but hinders mass transport. We tuned the irradiance of UVA light to provide adequate energy to the catalyst while minimizing carrier recombination, and we observed that at high flow rates, our system overcame mass transfer limitations and operated at a kinetically-limited reaction rate. We achieved a 100% yield for the conversion of H2S to sulfate, with a remarkable photonic efficiency of 30% and an electrical energy per order (EEO) of 0.1 kWh/m³/order. Notably, EEO values below 10 are considered commercially viable. Our operando studies suggest a photohole-driven mechanism and the formation of sulfide anion radicals at the TiO2 surface. Multicomponent removal of H2S with biological or H2S with heavy metal contaminants causes negligible fouling, with the photocatalyst showing only 12% degradation over ~24h in groundwater with >40 ppm TOC. Full photocatalyst recovery is achieved upon simple washing in clean water.

H2S removal is essential outside of water treatment as well. Several industrial processes, including those in petroleum refineries, paper mills, and tanneries, generate waste streams with dangerously high concentrations of H2S. Traditional removal methods employed such as advanced oxidation processes, membrane filtration, and adsorption have significant drawbacks including hazardous material disposal, complex setups, or difficult regeneration steps. Our system produces no intermediates, has exceptional energy efficiency, resists fouling in multicomponent matrices, and is easily regenerated, offering clear advantages over traditional removal methods for aqueous H2S.

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2025
Modified by: Kevin M McPeak
